did.unittitle: John S. Bradway correspondence with Richard M. Nixon
did.abstract: John S. Bradway was a professor to Richard Nixon while he was a student at Duke Law School in the 1930s. The collection consists of letters, telegrams, and cards sent to and from Richard Nixon prior to his 1968 election, during his presidency and subsequent impeachment, and following his resignation in 1974 during his second term in office. Topics in the correspondence include the Vietnam War, political protests, Nixon's coverage in the press, his impeachment trial, and his book.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Saeger Bradway (1890-1985) taught law at Duke University School of Law from 1931 to 1959, where Nixon was one of his students. Bradway taught in California until his retirement in 1970. Bradway was married to Mary Henderson in 1921. He died on January 2, 1985 in Eureka, California.

Richard Milhous Nixon (1913-1994) attended the Duke University School of Law from 1934 to 1937, graduating number three in a class of twenty-six. During his three years at Duke, Nixon was active in the Duke Bar Association and was elected President in his senior year. Following school, Nixon began a political career. He was a Senator for California (1950-1953), the nation's 36th vice president (1953 to 1961), and was elected the 37th president of the United States, serving from 1969 until his resignation in 1974.

Nixon was the first U.S. president, since Andrew Johnson in 1868, to be the subject of formal impeachment proceedings in the House of Representatives. The impeachment process began on October 30, 1973, following a series of staff firings and resignations known as the Saturday Night Massacre prompted by the Nixon administration's attempt to cover-up its involvement with the 1972 break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters at the Watergate office complex in Washington, D.C.

On May 9, 1974, formal hearings in the impeachment inquiry of President Nixon began, culminating July 27â€“30, 1974, when the Democratic-led Judiciary Committee approved three articles of impeachment charging the president with obstruction of justice; injury to the constitutional rights of citizens; and the abuse of power. Once Nixon was told his that both his impeachment and his conviction were inevitable he resigned the presidency on August 9, 1974, before the House could vote on the articles of impeachment.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of carbon copies of letters Bradway sent to Nixon, and letters, telegrams, and cards from Richard Nixon prior to his 1968 election, during his presidency and subsequent impeachment, and following his resignation in 1974 during his second term in office. Topics in the correspondence include the Vietnam War, political protests, Nixon's coverage in the press, his impeachment trial, and his book. Also included is correspondence between Bradway and President Gerald Ford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Content discusses Bradway's upcoming retirement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway's secretary, Rita Leavitt, writes to tell Nixon that Bradway is out of town, and has not received his invitation to a meeting at the Annual Meeting of the American Bar Association. The invitation is included with the letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon asks for Bradway's opinion on conservatives and liberals as TV and radio commentators, and his views on the student protests at the University of California, Berkeley.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter includes a copy of The Choice in Vietnam which is a speech delivered by Nixon at a meeting of the 87th, 88th, and 89th clubs in New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to congratulate Nixon on his election as President of the United States.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: As President, Nixon writes to Bradway discussing his stay in the hospital, and his memories of Bradway as a professor at Duke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway discusses that both he and Nixon received Quaker upbringings, and that he prays for him daily.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contents include correspondence between Harry Jeffrey and Bradway regarding interviewing Bradway for the Richard Nixon Oral History Project at California State College, Fullerton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a signed, printed card which discusses appreciation for support of pursuit of peace in Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway discusses his thoughts on a recommendation for the Supreme Court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an invitation to dinner at the White House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway declines an invitation to the White House and comments on the failure of the news media.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon recalls Bradway and faculty's kindness extended during his three years at Duke Law School, and states he will have Bradway's message to the Class of 1937 copied and sent to each member of the Class.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Content includes a printed telegram requesting Bradway's vote signed by Nixon and paid for by the Committee to Re-elect the President.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a signed, printed card which discusses appreciation for Bradway's message of congratulations. The card is also signed by Pat Nixon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway suggests having Congress investigate the possible origins of funding for "Peace Demonstrations" of the Vietnam War.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway suggests Nixon explore hiring George W. Kraft, a former Duke student, to ensure he have an honest man work for him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon wishes Bradway well during his upcoming surgery. Also included is a carbon copy of the letter to Ralph A. Newman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes signed, printed cards thanking Bradway for his support.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway comments on Senator Javits' speech, and the Republican Party's Watergate Affair mistakes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a Christmas card from the White House.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to Vice President Ford discussing the possibility of Congress, AFL-CIO, or the press as the pressure groups supporting Nixon's impeachment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway discusses the need for fairness in the impeachment coverage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon writes to Bradway on the occasion of his eighty-fourth birthday. A photocopy of the original letter is also included.

did.unittitle: Ralph A. Newman to John Bradway

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newman corresponds with Bradway regarding his upcoming birthday, and communications with Nixon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway encourages Nixon to "Stay With It," as the Congressional impeachment investigation continues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to Nixon to thank him for his birthday greeting letter, and also states that "your resignation would be a major catastrophe," and stating he will frame and hang his letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jan Fuller sends a clipping to Bradway regarding a missing Duke University Law School painting of Nixon found hidden in the ceiling of the building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes signed, printed cards thanking Bradway for his confidence and support.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes regarding Nixon's television presentation, and discusses confidentiality and the press.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes appreciation for Bradway's message and a copy of an article by Dean Burch, "What Nixon Knew, and When, and What He Did: A View."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway discusses his receipt of a letter from Senator Tower, and a copy of his response stating his disappointment with the Republican Party response to the impeachment.

did.unittitle: John Bradway to the American Bar Association

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway corresponds with Chesterfield Smith and Louis Potter of the American Bar Association (ABA) suggesting the ABA pursue a professional role in the upcoming impeachment trial.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes appreciation for Bradway's message of support, and copy of an article by Dean Burch, "What Nixon Knew, and When, and What He Did: A View."

did.unittitle: United States International University to John Bradway

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Robert K. Castetter, Dean of the School of Law responds to a letter from Bradway stating they will send him a copy of remarks made by speakers during the program honoring Bradway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes letters of support and comments that Nixon "will go down in history as one of our finest Presidents," as Nixon officially resigns the presidency on August 8, 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes expressing his disappointment in the Republican Party and choosing not to send a contribution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to "Richard" suggesting that he write books or articles on his side of Watergate Affair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway has suggestions for the new president regarding the Watergate Affair and the United States Constitution involving the issues of high crimes and misdemeanors, the Supreme Court, and due process of the law.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Wilson writes thanking Bradway for his support of the Republican party.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway has suggestions for Wilson including encouraging Nixon to write a book, and the issues of high crimes and misdemeanors, and the impeachment process.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Director of Public Information thanks Bradway for his letter on behalf of President Johnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon writes to Bradway commenting on his project of writing about the Watergate Affair.

did.unittitle: John Bradway to the Law Alumni Journal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to the editor to offer corrections to a reference to him in the journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes Nixon he is still thinking of the Watergate Affair, and that the Democrats' version seemed to be "a lot of shadow boxing but has little relation to the actual controversy."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to Korff with comments on his book The Personal Nixon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to Nixon that he read Rabbi Korff's book. Bradway also writes that press accounts of Nixon left him feeling that he was "witnessing a "lynching" party."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon writes that he is working his book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon thanks Bradway for his concern over Pat's illness, and gives a health update.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway thanks Ford for supporting his former law student, Nixon, while he faced "what some people would regard as a lynching party."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ford thanks Bradway for his kind message.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ford writes to thank Bradway for his support of the Republican National Committee, and includes photographs of himself and Betty Ford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to Nixon with comments on his television interview with David Frost.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon thanks Bradway for his comments on the interview, and notes he will try to incorporate Bradway's analysis in his book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon sends Bradway a copy of an article on the powers of the Presidency he as written for publication in The Washington Star.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon sends Bradway an autographed copy of his daughter Julie Nixon's book, "Special People."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon thanks Bradway for his letter regarding the last of the Frost television interviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bradway writes to Nixon to thank him for the autographed copy of his book, and offers his comments. Only the first page of the letter is included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nixon writes to Bradway thanking him for his comments on Memoirs, and mentioning memories of Mrs. Bradway forty years earlier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an advertising letter from Grosset & Dunlap, Inc., offering autographed Deluxe and Presentation Editions of Nixon's book, Memoirs.
